title: City Panel Expected to Recommend Closing Rikers Island, Report Says
text:
City Panel Expected to Recommend Closing Rikers Island, Report Says By Katie Honan | March 31, 2017 8:35am View Full Caption DNAinfo/Jeff Mays 
DNAinfo New York reported last year about the city's study to close Rikers and place smaller jails in communities around the five boroughs, an effort dubbed "Project Sean Connery," according to a presentation. 
Former New York state Chief Judge Jonathan Lippman, who is part of the group discussing the alternatives to the beleaguered Rikers, confirmed that the report expected to be released this weekend will recommend the city replace the correction complex with smaller jails around the city, according to the New York Post. 
READ MORE: ​► Rikers Island: The Evolution of City Hall's Search for a Fix 
According to the documents obtained by DNAinfo previously, the plans to close Rikers Island's jail facilities included a plan to replace it with smaller jails across the city, including two 1,500 to 2,000-bed facilities next to the new Police Academy in College Point and another next to the city's jail barge in Hunts Point. 
The rest of the inmate population would be housed in smaller jails in locations in East New York, Williamsburg and two on Staten Island, according to the study. The city began looking for alternatives at the end of summer 2015. 
de Blasio at the time denied the plan to close the large, controversial correction center — calling it a "noble concept" that couldn't work because it would "cost many billions" to do. 
Representatives for the mayor's office did not immediately respond to a request for comment on Friday.
